title: Susan B. Anthony Papers: Daybook and Diaries, 1856-1906; Diaries; 1904

entries.fullText:
To our beloved Miss
Anthony, abundance
Miss Donnelly
of love and thanks
and all kind wishes
for the New Year.
Mary D
entries.summaryText: Mary D sends love and New Year wishes to Susan B. Anthony and Miss Donnelly.

entries.fullText:
Susan B. Anthony
17 Madison Street
Rochester - N.Y.
This was the Christmas of
the Donelly girl of [?] [?] -
[?] of [?] - their sister Sarah
died - [?] [?] [?] [?] alone -
815 - Oak Street - S.F. Cal
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the Donelly family and their recent loss of Sarah.

entries.fullText:
To our beloved Miss
Anthony, abundance
Miss Donnelly
of love and thanks
and all kind wishes
for the New Year.
Mary D
entries.summaryText: A New Year's greeting from Mary D to Miss Anthony.

entries.fullText:
This was the champion of
Mrs. Donnelly girls of San Francisco -
Mary & (Louisa) - her sister Sarah
died - (? ? ? ?) alone --
818 - Oak Street -- S.F. Cal.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Mrs. Donnelly's girls in San Francisco and the death of Sarah.

entries.fullText: Mrs Stanton when asked to say grace always responded with alacrity - “Heavenly father and mother, make us thankful for all the blessings of this life and ever mindful of the patient hands that oft in weariness and toil prepare our daily food, for humanitys sake; Amen.” She said this once - where the man had entertained her with his talk - while the wife had wrestled with the dinner- her face red as a beet - and looking very tired & worn with much service - the man looked aghast - at her sacrilegious words - Humanity sake - instead of the “Lords Sake” - !!
entries.summaryText: Mrs Stanton says grace in a non-traditional way.

entries.fullText:
ROUTS OF TRAVEL
Modes of Conveyance, Distances and Rates of Fare from San Francisco

ABBREVIATIONS.

*--Southern Pacific Company, Foot of Market Street.
X--Southern Pacific Company (Coast Division). Third and Townsend Streets.
*N.G.--Southern Pacific Company, Narrow Gauge, foot of Market Street.
C. & C.--Carson & Colorado Railroad.
C. & L.--Colusa & Lake Railroad.
C. & N.--California & Nevada Railroad.
C. N. W.--California North-western Railroad.
E. & E.--Eel River and Eureka Railroad.
E. &. P.--Eureka & Palisade Railroad
L. A. T. R.--Los Angeles Terminal Railroad.
m.--Miles
Mt. Ts.--Mt. Tamalpais Scenic Railroad.
N. C.--Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad.
N. P.--Northern Pacific Railroad.
N. S.--North Shore Railroad.
O. C. & E.--Oregon Central & Eastern Railroad.
O. P.--Oregon Pacific Railroad.
O.R.N.--Oregon Railway & Navigation Co.
O. S.--Oceanic.Steamship Co.
P. C.-Pacific Coast Steamship Co.
P. C. Ry.--Pacific Coast Railway.
p.--Population. Where no figures are given population is under 50.
R. G. W.--Rio Grande Western Railroad.
S. C.--Southern California Railroad
U. P.--Union Pacific Railway and Branches.
V. & T.--Virginia & Truckee Railroad

This is a stormy day -
no visitors - but Aunt Eliza W -
Anthony, our Samuel's son, he grandson
- Samuel E. Anthony from
Red Creek - he came last night
Went with sister Mary & me to
Lila Heaths party - some 30 or 40 -
— old & young — rich & very poor — did
not go to Mrs H. B. Montgomerys reception -
entries.summaryText: Attended Lila Heath's party with Aunt Eliza W-Anthony, Samuel E. Anthony, and sister Mary.

entries.fullText:
Miss Shaw came in 6.45, on
the Lehigh Valley Road - to breakfast
with us - it is very snowy & [?],
so we gathered round them -
Miss Shaw dictated some letters to
Mrs Butler —
entries.summaryText: Had breakfast with Miss Shaw and dictated letters to Mrs. Butler.

entries.fullText: A stormy day - but decided to take the matter calmly — there has not been a real pleasant Sunday evening in the whole ten - all stormy- but Miss Shaws audience was the best of the lot - and her lecture the very best - excepting Mrs Catts - I have heard only 4 of the 10- lectures
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a stormy day and attending Miss Shaw's lecture.

entries.fullText: One vols. IV. one set Life & book. one full set - Both - 11. letters - Miss Shaw got up a 4:00. got her breakfast - & found her train had gone - & the next one was 4 hours later - - wouldn’t get here until 11:20 - so she left for Buffalo on that —
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Miss Shaw missing her train and leaving for Buffalo.

entries.fullText: 14 Letters— & no books sent out- 102 - Vols 3 delivered - 8 White & Burke - The weather has moderated a little —
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about bookkeeping and the weather.

entries.fullText:
4 Packages-
28- letters -
Went to
Mrs. Fullams this A.M. to talk
about new best dress - it five years
since my plain satin was made -
Called at Rabbi Landsburg - then
at Dem & Chron. office - It was
Mr Main that wrote the editorial
Dec 21st - on Mrs H. introduction -
— saw & congratulated Mr.
Willard on his marriage -
- Cousin Lucien Squier [died to day]
was buried to day
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony talks about her dress and visits Mrs. Fullams, Rabbi Landsburg, and Dem & Chron. office. She also congratulates Mr. Willard on his marriage and mentions the death and burial of Cousin Lucien Squier.

entries.fullText: Ther.
entries.summaryText: No significant events mentioned.

entries.fullText:
15 - Letters — 2. packages
Cousin Carrie Vail Ladd
wrote me to day their cousin
& Ellen Hoxie’s husband - Lucien
Squier was buried yesterday -
& was carried to Greenwood Cemetery
to day -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives letters from Cousin Carrie Vail Ladd and mentions the burial of Lucien Squier at Greenwood Cemetery.

entries.fullText:
Did not go to Church
Mrs Leroy - of [Str????] - [?] -
read or delivered a lecture about
Browning in our parlor this
evening - some 30 or 20 came -
Harriet May Mills staid
all night - going to speak
at Wyoming - etc -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony does not go to church and instead attends a lecture about Browning delivered by Mrs. Leroy. Harriet May Mills stays overnight and is going to speak at Wyoming.

entries.fullText:
55 - Letters - mostly to normal
schools -
next to Mrs Fullams - tried on dress linen -
Call at Mrs Fullams at 3 P.M.
Wrote cousin Ellen Hoxie Squier
to day - she is left with her three
sons - two are married - one is not -
to lean on - told her she could
live without Lucian a great deal
better than he could without her -
entries.summaryText: Susan writes about writing letters, visiting Mrs. Fullams, and writing to her cousin Ellen Hoxie Squier.

entries.fullText:
Mailed 11 Letters
Mrs Butler writing to
normal school & College
Libraries -
After dinner - I was
all ready & dressed to go to Mrs
Fullams again - when all turned dark
and for an hour I felt pretty un-
certain of myself - vomited - and had a
pain on the left side - that seemed
ominous - but Mrs Butler went to
Mrs Fullams with the [pieces?] had
come - so must go again
entries.summaryText: Susan writes about mailing letters, feeling ill, and Mrs. Butler going to Mrs. Fullams.

entries.fullText:
40 Letters to libraries -
Went to Mrs Fullams alone at
11 Oclock - saw the samples
and decided which to have - it is a
brocade - but still felt badly,
lay upon the sofa in office
and dictated but luckily I
had work planned for Mrs Butler
Sarah Burbeck Read - taken
ill to day - she was the wife of Daniel
Stafford Read - of Palatine Bridge. - N.Y.
entries.summaryText: Susan writes about writing letters, visiting Mrs. Fullams, and Sarah Burbeck Read being taken ill.

entries.fullText:
6 Letters
Still dizzy headed - when
combing my hair - Laid on the
longue all this day = with my
wrapper on. and dictated letters -
entries.summaryText: Susan writes about feeling dizzy and dictating letters.

entries.fullText:
7 Letters - 2 packages
Feel better - home worked all
slowly at my desk -
got a lot of letters - some from the
old work - Wrote long letter to Ms Catt -
Jenning - of Oregon. Anna Shaw and
Ms Sewall -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about receiving letters and writing a long letter to Ms Catt, Jenning, Anna Shaw, and Ms Sewall.

entries.fullText:
17, letters - & 4. packages
1 set leather book letters at home -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about receiving 17 letters and 4 packages and getting a set of leather book letters at home.

entries.fullText:
"CANAJOHARIE, N. Y., JAN. 19, 1904
- Mrs. Sarah Read, who has been in
poor health for sometime, suffered a
shock of paralysis on Wednesday after-
noon, at the home of Mrs. Geo. Watson
in Frankfort, with whom she makes her
home. For a time she was unable to
speak, but the paralysis of the vocal or-
gans has since been relieved and she is
quite comfortable. Mrs. Willis Bullock
went to Frankfort upon receiving word
of Mrs. Read's illness. "
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Mrs. Sarah Read's illness and Mrs. Willis Bullock going to Frankfort upon receiving word of Mrs. Read's illness.

entries.fullText:
Ten letters; two
packages.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about receiving ten letters and two packages.

entries.fullText:
Sixteen letters; five
packages.
George Francis Train -- died
this A.M. at the Mills Hotel
in New York - his daughter
"Sue", he always called her --
was notified -- she lives at Stamford - Conn.
Susan Train Gulager -- two sons live
in California --
entries.summaryText: George Francis Train died in New York. His daughter Sue was notified. Susan Train Gulager has two sons living in California.

entries.fullText:
Eleven letters.
A telegram came this evening
saying that Aunt Amy Read
Howes youngest son - Lucius L.
Howe - died this evening -- He would
be 85 - in March.
Fearfully cold, & miserable weather
Cousin Lucius was the last of my
mother's sister - Amy's children - so
we [?] - he leaves two daughters -
in poor circumstances financially
entries.summaryText: Aunt Amy Read Howes youngest son, Lucius L. Howe, died. He was the last of Amy's children and leaves two daughters in poor financial circumstances.

entries.fullText:
Six letters; two
packages.
This was a fearful snowy
blowing day -- it cleared off
at night -- & the wind calmed down
Mary & I went to the P. E.
reception -- at Joseph B. Bloss'.
Gilbert Mason took supper with
us & then went with us. The
snow was very deep -- went in a
carriage --
entries.summaryText: Susan and Mary went to a P. E. reception at Joseph B. Bloss' during a snowy day. Gilbert Mason joined them for supper.

entries.fullText:
Thirty letters.
It was so rainy this
forenoon that sister Mary
did not go to Geneva - to the
funeral at 2 o'lock --
There goes the
youngest & last child of Aunt Amy.
A letter came from cousin
Nancy Howe Clarks -- only daughter
Emily -- Tuesday A.M. -- There are other
nieces & nephews -- but do not know if they were there,
entries.summaryText: Mary did not attend the funeral in Geneva due to the rainy weather. A letter came from cousin Nancy Howe Clarks about the funeral of the youngest and last child of Aunt Amy. Emily, Nancy's only daughter, was there but it is unknown if other nieces and nephews attended.

entries.fullText:
Went to try on my dresses at
Mrs. Fullams - they are very nice-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to try on her dresses at Mrs. Fullams.

entries.fullText:
Staid at home and
read all the morning - Until
Frank Mosher brought the
mail - Letter from Mrs. Catt
announced her determination - final
not to stand for President - I
was swiftly dismayed - we all thought
she consented at Phila. What has changed
her mind ||
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a letter from Mrs. Catt announcing her final determination not to stand for President, which dismayed her.

entries.fullText:
Forty-six letters;
Four packages by
express and two by
mail.
Very cold but - sun
shining - for the first in a
long time
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received 46 letters and 4 packages, and it was very cold but sunny.

entries.fullText:
13. letters - 4 foreign
wrote Hattie I would
postpone going to Ithica until
after the Wash. Con. - looking
over old books - I found not in regular
diary - an account of trip home from
California in 1871 & 72 - Most interesting
- had it copied and going to send it
to Mrs Sargent - -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote 13 letters, including one to Hattie about postponing her trip to Ithica, and found an interesting account of her trip home from California in 1871 & 72 that she copied and planned to send to Mrs. Sargent.

entries.fullText:
4 letters
Wea. Thursday 28 Ther.
Anna Dann Mason
arrived home at 8 this evening
her husband - Gilbert Mason
was waiting at the station
for her
entries.summaryText: Anna Dann Mason arrived home and was greeted by her husband Gilbert Mason.

entries.fullText:
five letters;
went to photographer
Hoyt - East Avenue - to have
picture taken - for Miss
Bessie Fitch - who has
charge of Sunday Herald
women's department - Sister
May went to Dante [?] of
the Church parlor -
Anna Dann called & told us
about her mothers death —
entries.summaryText: The author went to a photographer and Anna Dann called to inform them of her mother's death.

entries.fullText:
A paper sent by Genevieve
L. Hanby - brings word that
Sarah Burbank Read - had a
stroke of paralysis. the 19th inst
entries.summaryText: The author received news that Sarah Burbank Read had a stroke of paralysis.

entries.fullText:
Went to church - just
11 weeks - at home - the
weather has been so cold
& snowy & windy & rainy -
entries.summaryText: Went to church after being home for 11 weeks due to bad weather.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Blackall & her
daughter - Florence -
called late - this eve'g
Fifteen letters;
entries.summaryText: Received a visit from Mrs Blackall and her daughter Florence and received fifteen letters.
Spent the day catching up on things and received eighteen letters.

entries.fullText:
15 introductions; 4 letters;
Counted up the
Vols. IV - sent out - they are
820 - vols I, 22 - vols II - 22 -
vol. III - 32 - Full sets. 120 -
money received - $2,001.17-
Express & mail - $419.52-
and expense on book paid
for - $252.82 - - so that 166.70
$166.70 - paid for them given away
entries.summaryText: Made 15 introductions and received 4 letters. Counted the number of books sent out and money received from sales and expenses.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
74 introductions;
letters; two
packages.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about introductions, letters, and packages.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
Left Rochester on the
6.44 train - arrived at
Washington D.C. at 7.15 - a
little late - on Northern Central
all the Committee
here - at the
Shoreham Hotel
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Rochester to Washington D.C. and stays at the Shoreham Hotel with the Committee.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
The Business Committee
all here -
At the Shoreham
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony mentions the Business Committee being at the Shoreham Hotel.

entries.fullText:
In Business Committee
session
Ms. Catt promised
after due deliberation
to take the Vice presidency
if Miss Shaw would
take the Presidency
so that question would be
settled and not a break
in appearance to the world -
entries.summaryText: Ms. Catt promised to take the Vice presidency if Miss Shaw would take the Presidency.

entries.fullText: I business Comm. Session
entries.summaryText: Attended Business Committee Session.

entries.fullText: Business Com -
entries.summaryText: Attended Business Committee Session.

entries.fullText:
Convention opened
this P.M. at evening - Mrs
Upton & I left & attended
the Army & Navy reception
at the White House - President
Roosevelt & his wife very gracious
entries.summaryText: Attended Army & Navy reception at the White House with Mrs Upton and met President Roosevelt and his wife.

entries.fullText: Convention
entries.summaryText: Convention

entries.fullText: Convention
entries.summaryText: Convention

entries.fullText:
The Board - & 8 others
were at breakfast at
12 oclock - noon - at
Mrs Mary Foote Hendersons -
Reception at the
Banquet Hall of
the Shoreham this
evening -- snowing -
entries.summaryText: Breakfast at Mary Foote Henderson's, Reception at the Shoreham

entries.fullText:
Pleasant
84th Birthday - now started
into my 85 year - - the President
& Mrs. Roosevelt - received the
delegates & friends at 2.00 - They
were both very kind in their
greeting - after the White House
reception - the delegates all went
to Glen Echo - to call on Clara
Barton - the cold was severe but
they had nice time - I decided not
to go - went to bed - so as to be
ready for the evening - Colorado night
entries.summaryText: Birthday celebration, White House reception, visit to Glen Echo

entries.fullText:
This was Colorado night
- Mrs. Grenfell spoke
beautifully - no display-
but - just told the facts
so did Ellis Meredith
Hearings this morning - Election
of officers this P.M. Rev. Anna
H. Shaw - Pres. and Mrs. [?]
Vice Pres - Miss Hay went out
of office - without Mrs. Catt --
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Grenfell and Ellis Meredith spoke about the facts on Colorado night. Rev. Anna H. Shaw was elected as President and Miss Hay went out of office without Mrs. Catt.

entries.fullText:
This was the last
day - Harriet Stanton
Blatch - spoke - she
disappoints me - she is
more like her father than
her mother --
entries.summaryText: Harriet Stanton Blatch spoke on the last day and disappointed the author as she was more like her father than her mother.

entries.fullText: Business Com. meeting
entries.summaryText: There was a Business Com. meeting.

entries.fullText:
Left Washington at 8:30
had long days ride - got
home about 9 evening --
entries.summaryText: The author left Washington at 8:30 and arrived home around 9 in the evening after a long day's ride.

entries.fullText: Wea. Sun. Feb. 28, 1904 Ther.
Wea. Monday 29 Ther.
Wea. Tues. March 1, 1904 Ther.
Wea. Wednesday 2 Ther.

Sister Mary went up to albion
at 2.30 P.M. - found Mary
Lorinda Read Loomis very
sick - she had plenty of
friends to care for her--
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary visits Albion and finds Mary Lorinda Read Loomis very sick with plenty of friends to care for her.

entries.fullText:
We got a postal card in morning
from Mrs. Rogers, saying
our cousin was very ill - not
expected to live - she
is Uncle Joseph Reads, son
Carlos Read's daughter - she
was the one descendant of his -
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Rogers sends a postal card informing us that our cousin, Uncle Joseph Reads' son Carlos Read's daughter and the one descendant of his, is very ill and not expected to live.

entries.fullText:
Poor Lorinda has had
a hard life of it - She
has worked as few others
have done - Taken care of
his father & mother - The
mother gave deed of place to
her - by that means they
have left a home - She has
one son - he lost his wife
entries.summaryText: Lorinda has had a hard life taking care of her father and mother and has been given a home by her mother.

entries.fullText:
several years ago. The daughter
about 18 - Live - to take care of
the two men now -
entries.summaryText: There is a daughter who is 18 years old and is taking care of two men.

entries.fullText:
Cousin Lorinda died
Wednesday evening at 10 Oclock
after Mary left - at 5 P.M.
She was buried this day at
2 P.M. Sister Mary went up
again to the funeral - the
Universalist minister preacher - a
great many there - neither
her husband - Frederick Somiers -
nor her son were able to come
down & stay throug the service
entries.summaryText: Lorinda died and was buried on the same day. Mary attended the funeral but Lorinda's husband and son were unable to attend.

entries.fullText:
Anna Dann came to day
got off twenty letters or now
entries.summaryText: Anna Dann visited and letters were sent.

entries.fullText:
Paid off the last peny for
the printing & binding of vols
I, II, III, IV - one thousand copies -
It takes almost
the last cent I have in bank -
- So - far I still have $1,200
in the Fidelity Bank - I have
come out a great deal
better than I ever expected —
Anna Dann Mason here
to day - she seems worried about
her brothers & sisters —
entries.summaryText: Printing and binding costs paid off. Anna Dann Mason visited and expressed concern for her siblings.

entries.fullText: Wea. Tues. March 15, 1904 Ther
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a brief entry on March 15, 1904.

entries.fullText: Wea. Wednesday 16 Ther
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a brief entry on March 16, 1904.

entries.fullText:
Wea. Thur. March 17, 1904 Ther
Anna Dan not feeling
well, so isn't coming tomorrow
entries.summaryText: On March 17, 1904, Susan B. Anthony wrote about Anna Dan not feeling well and not being able to come the next day.

entries.fullText:
Wea. Friday 18 Ther.
Started to go Dr. Holdren's
to get teeth made -- to see if she
couldn't fit them better than
Dr. Requa - Immediately my
right knee hurt me so - that
I came back - & gave up going --
entries.summaryText: On March 18, 1904, Susan B. Anthony wrote about starting to go to Dr. Holdren's to get teeth made but had to come back due to her right knee hurting.

entries.fullText:
Dr Rucker called
He says my trouble is
rheumatism - Not at
all like paralysis -
entries.summaryText: Dr Rucker called and diagnosed Susan's trouble as rheumatism.

entries.fullText:
Pearl Knowles
has been my stenographer &
type writer for a half -day
for the last two weeks -
Anna Dann not well -
I went to Dr. Reids
to take Osteopathic treatment
& try what it would do for
my legs - knees, calves &
feet - - he gave me a regular
rubbing from head to foot
Slept without hot water - for
the first time this winter
entries.summaryText: Susan writes about her stenographer, Anna Dann's health, and her visit to Dr. Reids for osteopathic treatment.

entries.fullText:
My annuity of $800 -
The quarterly payment is due
this day - I must write the
Penn Mutual that "I still Live"
It is just a week 5 days
since my legs were so weak & painful
in walking - that Mrs. Hallowell
had her man bring me home -
entries.summaryText: Susan receives her quarterly annuity payment and writes to Penn Mutual. She also mentions her recent leg pain and weakness that required assistance from Mrs. Hallowell.

entries.fullText: Ther.
Ther.

Sister Marys 77th
Birth-day - now she starts
in for her 78th - and soon
she will be to 79, then 80 - -
she seems very well & strong - has
lost nothing her hearing - and
she is quite deaf in one ear
entries.summaryText: Celebrating Sister Mary's 77th birthday.

entries.fullText:
Cold - but sunshine -
May Wright Sewall - came at
10.30 - and staid. until 9 P.M.
and talked every minute of the day -
she is to sail for Berlin on May. 19th
Mrs Ellis -the wife of Superintendent
Public School - died to
night - she had been to Church
& Sunday school in the A.M.
and sitting at table with
her grandson Ellis
she suddenly was gone -
entries.summaryText: May Wright Sewall visits and Mrs. Ellis dies suddenly.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
Cold but clear. It does
seem as if winter could
not let go -

Harriet Purvis died this evening -
she was the only surviving daughter
of the noble Robert Purvis - she
lived with her niece - Alice
H. Purvis - M.D. - no 70.-a
Mt Auburn Street - Watertown
Mass -
entries.summaryText: Harriet Purvis, the only surviving daughter of Robert Purvis, died in Watertown Mass.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
Mrs Ellis was buried
this 4.30 - this P.M. & the funeral
was then - she is to [?] at [?] -
she was 82 years old
[*Frances Power Cobbe Dead.
London, April 5. - Frances Power C
the authoress, is dead. She was born in *]
entries.summaryText: Mrs Ellis was buried and Frances Power Cobbe died in London.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
This A.M. mail brot a letter
from Dr Charles Purvis - that
his sister - Harriet Purvis
died Monday night - suddenly -
- Poor girl - she suffered all
the torments of the prejudice
against class & caste - though
she herself was almost as white
as any of the Brunette order -
her niece Alice is all that was
left to her - the Dr gave no particulars
entries.summaryText: Dr Charles Purvis informed Susan B. Anthony that his sister Harriet Purvis died suddenly and suffered from prejudice against class and caste.

entries.fullText:
My lameness - of
my right leg - some
better - but far from
strong - both knees
are weak -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her ongoing leg issues.

entries.fullText:
Did not go to Church -
Mr & Mrs Greenleaf, Mr -
Rev. Asa Saxe - and Mrs
Lewis C. Smith - now 92. years
of age - were here to dinner -
It eight years since Mr Greenleaf
had a stroke of paralysis - and
he can walk & talk - but
imperfectly - has to have a man
nurse - all the time - a very
pleasant visit -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about having guests over for dinner.

entries.fullText:
Went to Mrs Fullam's at
2 Oclock - to see about her
making the drab dress that
dear Rachel gave me last
Dec. when she visited us - made
her farewell visit - she went to Vevey -
Switzerland - early in January - to the
surprise of all - -
Then I took an Osteopath
rubbing - of Dr -
next door to Mrs Fullams - then went
to meeting at Local Council - Then
home - [?] - & went to bed before 8.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about visiting Mrs. Fullam and getting an Osteopath rubbing.

entries.fullText:
Wrote Miss Shaw and Lucy E.
a good by note - this evening
- they are to sail the 14th --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a goodbye note to Miss Shaw and Lucy E. as they were to sail on the 14th.

entries.fullText:
Received letter written yesterday
from Rev Anna Shaw.
She & Lucy E. intend to go
into New York at 11. to night
to be ready in the morning
to go on board at 10 o'clock
Anna been here & worked all day
her type writing is so much better
than anybody else & I am so very
glad she feel like coming on two
days every the week -- she comes for
a trial on Tuesday & Fridays --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a letter from Rev Anna Shaw and she and Lucy E. were going to New York to board a ship. Anna was there and worked all day and was going to come on Tuesdays and Fridays.

entries.fullText:
Rev. Anna H. Shaw & Niece
Lucy E. Anthony are to sail
for Genoa on the "Prinz Oskar"
this day --
entries.summaryText: Rev. Anna H. Shaw and Lucy E. Anthony sailed for Genoa on the "Prinz Oskar".

entries.fullText: Anna Dann here to day
entries.summaryText: Anna Dann was there that day.

entries.fullText:
Wea. Sunday 17 Ther.
Snow [?] of a foot deep & came
the night of the [?] -- according to
the days of the week it is just
70 years ago this very day since
brother J. Merritt was born -- how
long it is -- but seems very short -- little
Eliza was then 2 years old -- she was
the brightest little thing -- mother was
almost distracted -- I was 14 years old --
Guelma 2 years older & Hannah younger -- &
Elmina -- to do the work -- the school
in the house -- Mary Perkins the
teacher - - how it all comes back.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the snow and remembers her brother J. Merritt's birth 70 years ago, describing the family and their situation at the time.

entries.fullText:
Went to Dr.
Holdren this A.M.--Miss Mills
left for Walcott -- It was real
good to have with us last night --
In P. M. went Mrs Fullams to try
on dress -- then to [?] osteopaths
then to Mr Han--to see about
shoes -- Mrs Wilder Duprey called --
Mr Gannett called at 9. -- & staid
till near 11. Oclock. I was just
closing up for the night -- his
boy Lewis -- has had rheumatic fever --
sick for a week -- strange --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her daily activities, including visiting the doctor, trying on a dress, and receiving visits from acquaintances, including Mr. Gannett whose son is sick with rheumatic fever.

entries.fullText:
Brother J. Merritts 70th birth-day -
and 4 years next June 7, since he passed away -
The sun shining - but snow on
the ground -- a fresh storm last night
I wrote brother Daniel this
A.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her deceased brother J. Merritt's 70th birthday and the weather, and mentions writing to her brother Daniel.

entries.fullText:
"Grace Greenwood" Dead. 1904
New York, April 21. - Mrs. Sarah
Jane Loppincott, better known as
"Grace Greenwood," under which
name she wrote many stories for chil-
dren, died tonight at the home of her
daughter, Mrs. Herbert Winslow, in
New Rochelle. Mrs. Lippincott was
eighty years old, and for some time
had been a sufferer from asthma. Her
maiden name was Clarke and she was
born in Pompey, Onondaga county.
In 1853, she was married to Leander
K. Lippincott of Philadelphia.
entries.summaryText: Sarah Jane Loppincott, better known as "Grace Greenwood," died at the home of her daughter in New Rochelle. She was eighty years old and had been a sufferer from asthma. Her maiden name was Clarke and she was born in Pompey, Onondaga county. In 1853, she was married to Leander K. Lippincott of Philadelphia.

entries.fullText:
(upside down)
including date of sale, at rate of $22,-
25 from Geneva. These tickets will
not be valid for passage on the "20
Century Limited," "Lake Shore Lim-
ited" or "Empire State Express."
They will be good in Pullman cars up-
on payment of Pullman charges.
Coach excursion tickets, limited to
leave St. Louis within ten days from
date of sale, will be sold to St. Louis
only, on specified dates. The rates
(cut off)
entries.summaryText: Ticket information including rates and limitations.

entries.fullText:
Grace Greenwood was always
true to the Woman Suffrage cause.
her letters to the Philadelphia Press
from Washington in 1869 - prove it - but
of late years she was in great suffering
from asthma - She was 80 years
old.
entries.summaryText: A tribute to Grace Greenwood's dedication to the Woman Suffrage cause.

entries.fullText:
Attended Church = The
first in eight weeks -
entries.summaryText: Attended church for the first time in eight weeks.

entries.fullText:
This A.M. 10 oclock -
went to Judge A. Sutherland
Court to witness the trial
Ethel Jackson - against
Wagar - for crime of abortion -
went morning & afternoon -
All the day - long - it is
a brutal [?] of trying
a young girl of 16= he
commence to tamper with
her at thirteen - Jury [?]
in A.M. Ethel on stand in P.M.
entries.summaryText: Attended the trial of Ethel Jackson against Wagar for the crime of abortion. Ethel was on the stand all day and it was a brutal experience.

entries.fullText:
Went to court again -
Ethel on the stand - Cross
questioned by George Raines
all the day long -
entries.summaryText: Attended the trial of Ethel Jackson against Wagar for the crime of abortion. Ethel was cross-questioned by George Raines all day long.

entries.fullText:
Went to Mrs Fullams -
dress maker - To try on Drab
dress that Rachel gave me -
and then took an osteopathic
treatment after it - Sister Mary
& I went to trial in A.M. and
Sister Mary went in P.M.
entries.summaryText: Went to Mrs. Fullam's dressmaker to try on a drab dress that Rachel gave me and then took an osteopathic treatment. Attended the trial in the morning with Sister Mary and Sister Mary went in the afternoon.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary went to court
to day--I had Anna Dann here
all day--wrote 20 letters--
[?] [?] [?] things.
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary went to court, Anna Dann visited, and 20 letters were written.

entries.fullText:
There was no court
went to the Dentist -- Dr
Holdrens - 70 - Union Street -
entries.summaryText: No court, went to the dentist.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary & I went to the
Church -- Mr Gannets subject
was the Church the Centre of
power to good with during -
week - - is was splendid--
Frank Rickenback called
Dr. Bruckants & Mrs. Bearsly
called -- the Dr to give me an Osteopath
treatment -- my right leg is some
better -- the pain is now in ankle
when I walk --
entries.summaryText: Attended church, received visitors, and received an osteopath treatment for leg pain.

entries.fullText: Bright & clear - the Wagar & Ethel Jackson trial begins its 2nd week - to drag it slow length - along Dr Holdren at 4. P.M,
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the Wagar and Ethel Jackson trial and meeting with Dr. Holdren.

entries.fullText: Took $500 - American Express checks - for European trip at Security Trust Bank Drew the small sums I had in the Fidelity = (the interest) - and the Mechanics, Rochester and Monroe County Banks to make it up - Paid Sister Mary the balance of 400. that I borrowed to pay Mrs. [Ma?] paid her the last 250 that Mrs Sewall paid her and now to $150 = making $400 -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony withdraws money for a European trip and pays off debts to Sister Mary and Mrs. Sewall.

entries.fullText: Wea. TUES. MAY 10, 1904 Ther.
Wea. WEDNESDAY 11 Ther.

Letters from Anna Shaw and Lucy E.
They landed April 20 - wrote them at
[?] - Switzerland -
Wea. FRIDAY 13 Ther.
entries.summaryText: Received letters from Anna Shaw and Lucy E. who landed in Switzerland on April 20th.

entries.fullText: Wea. FRIDAY 13 Ther.
Wea. Sat. May 14, 1904 Ther
Wea Sunday 15 Ther
Wea. Mon. May 16, 1904 Ther

Left Rochester - Sister Mary
& I at 9:05 A.M. arrived in
New York at 6. Telegraphed Cousin
S.V. Lapham that I arr at 6:30. So
missed Miss Powell & the carriage
which waited for us till the 6:30 -
We took cab to 10 East 68th Street
Found a warm welcome
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Sister Mary left Rochester and arrived in New York, where they missed Miss Powell and the carriage. They took a cab to 10 East 68th Street and found a warm welcome.

entries.fullText: Drove down to see Emily Clark Griggs - 41 East 10th Then went to see Mrs Matthews who is making a tripple medallion of Mrs Mott, Mrs Stanton & me - I had not notified Jefferson Arthur or Harry of 'our coming -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony drove to see Emily Clark Griggs and then went to see Mrs. Matthews who is making a triple medallion of Mrs. Mott, Mrs. Stanton, and Susan B. Anthony. She had not notified Jefferson Arthur or Harry of their coming.

entries.fullText: Miss Powell - Cousin Semanthas House keeper - went with us in a carriage - to the S. S. Frederick de Grosse - where we met Mrs Harper, Mrs G M - and a dozzen others - we [?] at 11 oclock - The Brooklyn Clarks came over - to see us off - Mrs Blankenberg - of Phila - with us Miss Powell & the man went clear into the cabin to see that we were comfortably [????ted] -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went with Miss Powell to the S. S. Frederick de Grosse where they met Mrs. Harper, Mrs. G M, and a dozen others. The Brooklyn Clarks came over to see them off. Mrs. Blankenberg of Phila was with them. Miss Powell and the man went clear into the cabin to see that they were comfortably situated.

entries.fullText: On ship -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was on a ship.

entries.fullText: On ship board
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was on a ship board.

entries.fullText: On Sh
entries.summaryText: Journal entry on Sunday, May 22, 1904, written on a ship with a short entry.

entries.fullText: On Ship
entries.summaryText: Journal entry on Monday, May 23, 1904, written on a ship with a short entry.

entries.fullText: On ship
entries.summaryText: Journal entry on Tuesday, May 24, 1904, written on a ship with a short entry.
Journal entry on Wednesday, May 25, 1904, written on a ship with no entry.

entries.fullText: On Ship
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote on Thursday, May 26, 1904 while on a ship.

entries.fullText: On Ship
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote on Friday, May 27, 1904 while on a ship.

entries.fullText: on ship
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote on Saturday, May 28, 1904 while on a ship.

entries.fullText: On Ship
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote on Sunday, May 29, 1904 while on a ship.

entries.fullText:
We land at Bremer Harbor
at 7. A.M - met Niece Frau
Hoffman & Frau Smidt, who
greeted us warmly & escorted
us to Bremen - to the
Hotel - They took us
a drive - and at 5. P.M
gave us a reception in the
[?] [?] The American Counsell
welcomed us - he is a strong friend
of W.S..
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives at Bremer Harbor and is greeted by Niece Frau Hoffman and Frau Smidt. They take her to Bremen and give her a reception in the [?]. The American Counsell welcomes her.

entries.fullText:
We left Hotel
Bremen for Berlin - Mrs
Catt, Mrs. Blakenburg - Sister Mary
& self - Mrs Francis along - the
rest - Staid till a later train
to meet Mrs May Wright Sewall
who was to land on Tuesday -
We stopped at the Palast
Hotel - - Mrs Wegman, Mrs
Perkins Gillium, Miss Belle [?]
went to [?] [H???] -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Bremen for Berlin with Mrs Catt, Mrs. Blakenburg, Sister Mary, and Mrs Francis. They stop at the Palast Hotel and meet with Mrs Wegman, Mrs Perkins Gillium, and Miss Belle [?].

entries.fullText:
The women came
without Mrs Sewall - she
would not get her trunks
through the Custom House
in time - so she came
on later train - Mrs
Harper & sister Mrs. Troch.
came with Mrs Pierce -
Miss Shaw & Miss Lucy E.
arrived from Vevey - Switzerland
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's group arrives in Berlin without Mrs Sewall, who comes later due to issues with customs. Mrs Harper and Mrs. Troch arrive with Mrs Pierce. Miss Shaw and Miss Lucy E. arrive from Vevey, Switzerland.

entries.fullText:
At Palast hotel -
Frau Stritt & Baroness
von Beswatesh - called
they were much [?]
about Frau Cawer & Fraulein
Augsburg having called a public
meeting on Monday night June 6th
They had broken their promise - they
were to hold only the [?]
meetings before the Council —
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with Frau Stritt and Baroness von Beswatesh at the Palast hotel. They express concern about Frau Cawer and Fraulein Augsburg calling a public meeting on June 6th, which goes against their promise to hold only the [?] meetings before the Council.

entries.fullText: Business meeting of the Committee of International Woman Suffrage Alliance at Prince Albert Hall.
entries.summaryText: Business meeting of the Committee of International Woman Suffrage Alliance.

entries.fullText: Business Meeting - International Suffrage Alliance - at Prince Albert Hall.
entries.summaryText: Business Meeting - International Suffrage Alliance - at Prince Albert Hall.

entries.fullText: Meeting is American Church at - 5 P.M. - Miss Shaw read the lesson & prayer - Mrs Catt & I made speeches - the House was swiftly packed
entries.summaryText: Meeting at American Church with Miss Shaw and Mrs Catt as speakers.

entries.fullText: Meeting of the Executive Committee of the International Council - on the daytime Miss Shaw, Miss Catt
entries.summaryText: Meeting of the Executive Committee of the International Council with Miss Shaw and Miss Catt.

people: Mary Gerritt & Miss Mary Carey Thomas
entries.fullText:
At the Palast Hotel -
Council over - and women
begin to [?] - Mary
Gerritt & Miss Mary Carey Thomas
follow along
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about being at the Palast Hotel with Mary Gerritt and Miss Mary Carey Thomas after the council was over.
Susan B. Anthony did not write anything on this day.
Susan B. Anthony did not write anything on this day.

entries.fullText:
We left Berlin - & the
Palace Hotel at 1.50 - for
Dresden - Mrs Catt - Miss Shaw
& Lucy E. and Sister Mary & self -
Mrs Pierce & Miss Bird came too -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her companions leave Berlin and the Palace Hotel for Dresden, accompanied by Mrs. Catt, Miss Shaw, Lucy E., Sister Mary, Mrs. Pierce, and Miss Bird.

entries.fullText:
We called on Baroness von
Olga Bestwich - 5. Mozart [?]-
and found Frau Stritt there - the
Baroness mother was with her -
We all went Theatre - to
Opera this eve'g -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her companions visit Baroness von Olga Bestwich and Frau Stritt in Dresden, and attend a theater performance in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Swift arrived from Berlin
we all called at Frau Stritts
I called on Mlle Pennefocher
at her school - Lucy with me
she then - I am mixed about the
visit - but we went to the
old castle -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her companions visit Frau Stritt and Mlle Pennefocher in Dresden, and go to an old castle.

entries.fullText:
The Penyfocher drove us
to an old monastery - now a
gentlemans Challeax- most
elegant then to dinner - at [?]
of the village on the top of a [?]
never surrendered to Napoleon or
any other - Then drove back - & then
P. and the rest went to our [?] [?]
- & at 8. we all went
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her companions visit an old monastery, now a gentleman's chateau, and have dinner at a village on top of a hill that never surrendered to Napoleon or any other. Later, they all go somewhere at 8 pm.

entries.fullText:
We left Heideburgh at 8. A.M.
& arrived at Nuremberg -
and drove about
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and company left Heideburgh and arrived at Nuremberg.

entries.fullText:
We went to Strassburg -
saw the famous clock &
its 12 apostles turning round
& cross themselves & bow to the
savior on the cross - Then we
drove round to the Park -
This was the point of strategy
in the late May - 1870 - and
the French People have resented
that German - Alsace remains
French - though possessed by
the Germans
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and company visited Strassburg and saw the famous clock and its 12 apostles turning round. They also drove around the Park and learned about its history.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Catt, Miss Shaw & Lucy E.
went down the Rhine - &
Sister Mary & self took train for
[??way] - where we arrived at .7.
Rachel & the two girls - Rose &
Julia meeting us at Lusane -
- Rachel looks as well as ever
- but is suffering from the over -
strain of her 15 years of married
life - we went to a [Ponsion?] -
just round the corner from Rachels -
5. Ru de [Commineaix?] —

]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and company split up, with some going down the Rhine and others taking a train to meet Rachel and her daughters. They stayed at a Ponsion near Rachel's home.

entries.fullText: At Vevey
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Vevey on July 1, 1904.

entries.fullText: At Vevey
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Vevey on July 2, 1904.

entries.fullText: At Vevey
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Vevey on July 3, 1904.

entries.fullText: At Vevey -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Vevey on July 4, 1904.

entries.fullText: At Vevey
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Vevey on July 5, 1904.

entries.fullText: At Vevey
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Vevey on July 6, 1904.

entries.fullText: At Vevey
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Vevey on July 7, 1904.

entries.fullText: At Vevey
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Vevey on July 8, 1904.

entries.fullText:
At 3:30 - Rachel & Julia
went with us to Lusane - &
there we left for -
Madam Chapponniere met us
at station - and drove us to her
home - a beautiful place in
full view of Lake Geneva - it
seemed a paradise - after the
ponsion at Vevey - We had our last
cup of coffee with dear Rachel -
it seems so hard that she must
expatriate herself and her two girls but such
is life --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Lusane and Lake Geneva with Rachel, Julia, and Madam Chapponniere.

entries.fullText:
We were indeed in Clover -
all kinds of fruits & vegetables &
flowers - Dr. Harriet Frisby -
70 years of age - was here - She [wa??]
to be at Dear Dr. Clemena L Doziers
in New York - in 1864 - She remembered
my going there perfectly well - & I
just remembered her -- that was
just 40 years ago - how strange
Mrs Richart did not come on the
boat - this 18 miles from Geneva -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time in a garden with Dr. Harriet Frisby and reflects on a past visit to Dr. Clemena L Dozier's in New York.

entries.fullText:
Madam Chapponniere
went with us to Geneva - by boat
took us to see see Calvins College
& old Church - and the Town Hall
that was built in 1200 or so - We
saw the Alabama Claims Internation
room - & the council of 7. room .where
the old frescoes were of men with
feet & hands cut off - we met
Mrs Fidort at Madam a lovely
woman - & Miss Mr & Mrs G. went to station
with us - my first experience in a sleeping
car in [??ope] -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Geneva with Madam Chapponniere and sees Calvins College, the Town Hall, and the Alabama Claims International room.

entries.fullText:
We found a young lady
sent by Madam Morro - at
the station who could talk but
very little English - but she helped
us get our trunk & selves into a cab
for the New Hanau & [Dreff??] Station
train left at 10.20 - a dreadfully
hot dusty day - arrived at Mrs
Mariton Cort's at 7.30 Oclock P.M.
found a cordial welcome - our fine
rooms - We were tired beyond measure
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Mrs. Mariton Cort's and receives a warm welcome.

entries.fullText: Sister Mary & self went to American Express Co J.Waterloo Place - Grand - gave them our trunk keys - they are detained in the Custom House - though expressed through from Berlin -
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary and Susan B. Anthony went to the American Express Co J.Waterloo Place to retrieve their trunk keys which were detained in the Custom House, even though they were expressed through from Berlin.

entries.fullText: Called in morning on Mrs Fawcett & Miss Agnes Garrett two sisters - Miss Garrett is a Decorator - her cousin Rhoda used to be associated with her - Mrs Fawcett's daughter - Phillippa is superintendent of public schools in the Transval - South Africa - In the P.M. called on Mrs. Jacob Bright & Countess of Aberdeen - neither in - at 9 Oclock - Miss Shaw, Lucy E, & Mrs Catt called - they had just arrived found their place horrid - so have to look for another - Miss Mallones to dinner -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visited Mrs. Fawcett and Miss Agnes Garrett, two sisters, in the morning. In the afternoon, she called on Mrs. Jacob Bright and the Countess of Aberdeen, but neither were in. Later that day, Miss Shaw, Lucy E, and Mrs Catt arrived and found their place horrid, so they had to look for another. Miss Mallones joined them for dinner.

entries.fullText: At Mrs Stanton Coits - 30. Hyde Park Gate - London Eng. Mary with Mrs Coit - gone to look after trunk at J. Waterloo Place Mrs Catt & Miss Shaw came to dinner - Lucy E. too -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at Mrs. Stanton Coits in London, England. Mary went to look after their trunk at J. Waterloo Place. Mrs. Catt, Miss Shaw, and Lucy E joined them for dinner.

entries.fullText: A garden Party at Miss Hollands - at 4 P.M. some 2 or 3 hundred came - Miss Shaw & Mrs Catt spoke splendidly Mr & Mrs Haslam of Dublin - Miss Maud & Ashhurst Biggs - Sisters of Caroline - Miss Blatch was there - Lady Frances Balfour president Mrs Garrett Fawcett spoke - Ella Dietz Clyman - there - Lucy E. & I went to S. S. Minnetonka with Sister Mary in the A.M.. got back at 2. P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a garden party at Miss Hollands where Miss Shaw and Mrs. Catt spoke splendidly. Mr. and Mrs. Haslam of Dublin, Miss Maud and Ashhurst Biggs, Miss Blatch, Lady Frances Balfour, Mrs. Garrett Fawcett, and Ella Dietz Clyman were also in attendance. In the morning, Susan B. Anthony and Lucy E went to S. S. Minnetonka with Sister Mary and returned at 2 PM.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Coit went with me to call on
Dr Elizabeth Blackwell at Miss
Leigh Browne's - 58 - Porchester
Terrace - W. London - the
Dr seemed bright as ever -
She was glad to hear me
tell of her great work in
the United States - she lives
at Hastings-by the sea.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Dr. Elizabeth Blackwell in W. London and talks about her work in the United States.

entries.fullText:
Lucy came to Mrs Coits
at night - she has sister Marys
room -
entries.summaryText: Lucy comes to stay at Mrs. Coit's and stays in Mary's room.

entries.fullText:
Luncheon with Mrs Fenwick
Miller - at the Lyceum Club -
128 Picadilly - Miss Shaw & Mrs Catt
and then came at 4 to tea - Mrs
Bedford Fenwick - & Mrs Jacob Bright
& daughter - a nice time - went
to J Waterloo Place - got a letter from
Sister Anna - Mr Roehler is ordered
back to Manilla. again - so Niand
will have to go - hard - hard - Lucy
E. came to Mrs Coits with me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony has lunch with Mrs. Fenwick Miller and tea with Mrs. Bedford Fenwick and Mrs. Jacob Bright. She receives a letter from Sister Anna and learns that Mr. Roehler is ordered back to Manilla.

entries.fullText:
Spent the A.M. at home - went
with Mrs Coit a shopping - at 4 P.M.
to tea at Miss Zora Wallace - Mrs
May - Mrs Shepherds sister - from
New Zealand there -
Mrs Catt arrived - Lucy went to [?]
to see Mrs [Barn?????] in - with Mary, Mrs
Catt & Miss Shaw
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony goes shopping with Mrs. Coit and has tea with Miss Zora Wallace, Mrs. May, and Mrs. Shepherd's sister from New Zealand. Mrs. Catt arrives and Lucy goes to see Mrs. [Barn?????].

entries.fullText:
Walked with Lucy E in
Kensington garden & saw the
old palace in which Queen
Victoria was born - & purchased
a pair of gloves - for 37 1/2 - a pair
entries.summaryText: Walk in Kensington garden with Lucy E and purchase gloves.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Katherin [?eed] Ward & Mrs
[Ja?ice] Wilder Fletcher - called on
Mrs Coits -
entries.summaryText: Visit from Mrs Katherin [?eed] Ward and Mrs [Ja?ice] Wilder Fletcher.

entries.fullText:
go to Manchester - [20] 15 -,
to 6.41- Eastern Station - Mrs Edith
N. Nuttall - at Raynor
Proft - Bowdoin - Cheshire -
at [Chingham?] - we were
met by Mrs Nuttall - and
found her home palatial
her husband - Harry Jr. was out and at
a meeting -
entries.summaryText: Visit to Manchester and meeting with Mrs Edith N. Nuttall.

entries.fullText: Manchester - Garden Party - at Mrs Hyland's - Victoria Park - at 3.30 Oclock - Take Lunch with Miss Mason - after the meeting - about a hundred were present - It rained hard - We got to station & found Mrs Thomason [?] & carriage at station to meet us - Mrs Wolstenholm Elmy - went with us - We had beautiful rooms - But no Mr Thomason was present to greet us -
entries.summaryText: Attended a garden party in Manchester and stayed at Mrs. Hyland's.

entries.fullText: Mrs H. Lucas Thomason - Woodside Bolton - to stay [the ?] nights We took a long drive in A.M., at night Mr Franklin Thomason & wife dined with us - he is a beautiful spirit = Mrs T. has a great deal to be thankful for -
entries.summaryText: Drove in the morning and had dinner with Mr. Franklin Thomason and his wife in Bolton.

entries.fullText: Left Mrs Katharine Lucas Thomason's - (J. P. Thomason. M.P.) the daughter of Mrs Margaret Bright Lucas - [?] - Mrs T. and myself [?] drove & talked over everything - Mrs Elmy left at 4 P.M. for her house, Congleton -
entries.summaryText: Left Mrs. Katharine Lucas Thomason's and drove with her, and Mrs. Elmy left for her house in Congleton.

entries.fullText: Edinburgh - Newington House = Mrs Duncan McIarens - [?] left Bolton at 10 A.M. - arrived at Edinburgh at 4. - Dr Agnes McLaren met us at station - we had tea on arriving at Newington House - Miss Matheson was at dinner - We were all called into Mrs McL. room and met a hearty welcome
entries.summaryText: Arrived in Edinburgh and had tea at Newington House with Mrs. Duncan McIarens and met Dr. Agnes McLaren and Miss Matheson.

entries.fullText:
At Mrs McLarens -
From 4 to 6 - the friends were
invited to meet at the tea room
of the Caffe - about a hundred
came. Miss Shaw & self spoke
they all seemed pleased - We drove
around the old town - the Castle,
[?] gates - John Knox [?]
[?] & Mrs McLaren sent a letter
to the meeting - which Dr Agnes
read -
entries.summaryText: Meeting at the tea room of the Caffe and driving around the old town.

entries.fullText:
At Mrs McLarens -
Dr Agnes & Shaw & Lucy & I drove
to Craig Miller Castle - round
Arthurs seat - the Salsbury Craggs
- the poor children bare feet & all
the people had half-[?] - & were
all over the Hills - running & walking -
went in to see Mrs. McL. - she did
not dress & come out - but she was
very bright- she told me of Mrs
Methven's call - how pleased all
the people were
entries.summaryText: Driving to Craig Miller Castle and visiting Mrs. McL.

entries.fullText:
The sun shone bright a
few moments in the morning -
then it became hazy - I wrote a
letter to Mrs Gross - of our visit
here 5 years ago - Sister Mary has
now been at home almost a week -
Dined at 8.00 at Miss
Stevensons -
entries.summaryText: Writing a letter and dining at Miss Stevensons.

entries.fullText:
Left Mrs Priscilla Bright
McLarens - Newington House - no. 10
Blacket street - at 9.20 - for
Bristol Eng. - The Priestman sisters
entries.summaryText: Leaving Mrs. Priscilla Bright McLarens for Bristol Eng.

entries.fullText:
Bristol - Durdham Park -
Miss Anna R. Priestman -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about her visit to Bristol - Durdham Park to meet with Miss Anna R. Priestman.

entries.fullText:
We - Shaw & Lucy & self
took a long drive over the
high bridge & it was beautiful
at 4. about 50 friends of Suffrage
called - Margaret Farmer presented
a beautiful banquet - made a short
& beautiful speech - Mss Shaw & I spoke
& the Liberal member of Parliament.
it was lovely to see the three sisters
87.75.73 - all so interested --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went on a drive with Shaw and Lucy and attended a banquet with Margaret Farmer and a Liberal member of Parliament. She also saw three sisters who were all interested in suffrage.

entries.fullText:
Street - Somerset -
(Glastonbury Station) Mrs
Helen Bright Clark
W'm Clark. - 6 children - 2 boys
& 4 girls - boys in shoe manufacturing
with their father - Esther B. Clothier
married & member of the School.
Alice - is Supt of the women in her
fathers factory - & member of the
Board of Trustees of the Sanitorium
at Bath for Consumption -
the third one is a Liberal Federalism
Lecturer & the youngest is studying
medicine - all of them active - &
each has [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony met with Mrs. Helen Bright Clark and her family, including Esther B. Clothier and Alice, who were all active in various fields.

entries.fullText: Mrs Jacob Bright
entries.summaryText: Mrs Jacob Bright

entries.fullText:
At Ursula Miller Brights
her daughter - Esther Bright's
entries.summaryText: At Ursula Miller Brights her daughter - Esther Bright's

entries.fullText:
Arrived Mr Fisher Unwins -
Jane Colden's - in time for dinner
Mrs Helen R. C. Hirst -
Woburn Square - Bloomsburg -
London - W.C. - was visiting her
She is a [?] woman
entries.summaryText: Arrived Mr Fisher Unwins - Jane Colden's - in time for dinner. Mrs Helen R. C. Hirst was visiting her. She is a [?] woman.

entries.fullText:
Lucy E. brought letter
from Sister Mary - of the 21st July
saying that Brother Dan'l R. was
very ill - the morning Dem & Chron. said
dying at his house in Leavenworth - Kan.
but she got telegram saying don't come
till you hear again - he was better -
entries.summaryText: Brother Dan'l R. is very ill in Leavenworth - Kan.

entries.fullText: Miss Zora [?allanee] - called -
entries.summaryText: Miss Zora [?allanee] called.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Ormiston Chant
called - she talks a steady stream
about herself - never asked a word
about Miss Shaw, or Lucy - or me -
Mrs Hurst called - she is the
cousin of Mrs Jane Colden "[?']
her name is Mrs Hirst - now - she
is a [?] woman -
I dreamed brother D.R.
was dead - & saw the little [?]
& J.R. Jr - hid his lifeless form
good - by - it is a wonderful change
entries.summaryText: Mrs Ormiston Chant and Mrs Hurst called. Susan dreamed about brother D.R.

entries.fullText:
Sail for home - on the
Minnetonka - Atlantic Transport
Line - Rev Anna H. Shaw - & niece
Lucy E. Anthony in company -
We left London at 10.10 - and felt
glad to get on board a home
steamer - a letter from Mrs Coit
said she had a letter from sister Mary
& that niece Maud had written her
that brother D.R. was able to ride out
every day - it must have been a [?]
after news paper report of Jul 27 -
I went to bed - so didn't see
the sail out the mouth of the Thames
entries.summaryText: Susan sails for home on the Minnetonka with Rev Anna H. Shaw and Lucy E. Anthony.

entries.fullText:
The sea was calm - but the
wind blustered so round the
head of the [?] I could not
sleep - I imagined not a
wink - but of course I did
The weather is beautiful cool &
[?] - I took my sea bath
and felt invigorated - I took a
sleep in the P.M. or tried to -
but couldn't
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her experience on the steamer Minnetonka, including taking a sea bath and having trouble sleeping due to the wind.

entries.fullText:
Last night was a heavy
sea - but not a storm -
the wind blew through the
ventilators & kept me awake
Letters from dear Rachel & the
two girls - Rose & Julia - the latters
letters show the difference in the girls
- it is strange that born of the
same parents - they can be so unlike.
Poor Rachel - that she takes her
penalty for a [?] [?] [?]
philosophically - she has her two girls.
and they compensate
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives letters from Rachel, Rose, and Julia and reflects on the differences between the two sisters.

entries.fullText:
On board the steamer
Minnetonka - I slept this
night - the sea was very still -
but the tremor of the ship is something
to get used to -
I have thought & thought
of brother Dan'l - sister Marys letters
must have reached 3 [Na??er?as] Place
too late for steamer "I wait with
great fear the news on landing -
Poor Anna - Poor Maud - but they
will go together now - sure -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reflects on her journey on the steamer Minnetonka and worries about news from her family, particularly her brother Dan'l and sister Mary, and expresses sympathy for Anna and Maud.

entries.fullText:
We all took a scrub - Miss
Shaw really far from well - how
she is to get better is the question -
I slept good last night -
finished reading the Last days of
Pompayn" [underlined] - it is very graphic - in
its descriptions - it is a rainy or
foggy - or misty day -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony notes that Miss Shaw is unwell and reflects on her reading of The Last Days of Pompeii on a rainy day.

entries.fullText: Bright morning - more than half way across the Atlantic
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is more than halfway across the Atlantic on Thursday, August 18, 1904.

entries.fullText:
We landed about 11 Oclock -
The Customs Officer seeing my name on
the list came to me and said I need fear
no trouble that he would pass me -
Arthur A. Mosher & wife Mattie Brown
were at the wharf - so Lucy & Anna Shaw
went right to Phila. on the 1 Oclock train -
& I went home with sister [?]
& call on Dr Harry A. Baker. and
found they had a No. 2 - a boy
two weeks old - a perfect Harry - with
black eyes, dimple cheeks -
sent a telegram to brother D.R. --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Phila. and visited her sister and brother-in-law, and met with Arthur A. Mosher and his wife Mattie Brown. She also visited Dr. Harry A. Baker and sent a telegram to her brother D.R.

entries.fullText:
Left A.A. Moshers - & the N.Y.
Central Station at 8.30 - on the
Empire State train - and was
landed in Rochester just on time.
3.24 - [?] Sister Mary in waiting -
- The Times reporter was waiting for
me - John Denis - the father of [?]
& [?] came to Interview me - I gave
him account of my Eng. & Scotland
visits - Mrs. Blackall called - It was
good to be at home again.
Brother D.R. is somewhat better so
we shall not go up there just now
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Rochester and met with Sister Mary, John Denis, and Mrs. Blackall. She also gave an interview to The Times reporter and decided not to visit her brother D.R. who was somewhat better.

entries.fullText:
While, last night, I
have not felt better during
the voyage - this A.M. I had
no appetite - and after reading up
the letters that had accumulated
I lay down and by night
I felt something must be wrong
and telephone for the Dr. Richer. He was gone
but Dr Carter came in his stead
- I was dizzy & all askew -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony felt unwell and called Dr. Richer, but Dr. Carter came in his stead. She was dizzy and felt something must be wrong.

entries.fullText:
Still under the weather -
Dr. Carter came - and
gave me medicine - but
there was no getting up
and no writing letters
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was still unwell and Dr. Carter came to give her medicine. She was unable to get up or write letters.

entries.fullText: So so - not much better -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a short entry about feeling slightly better.

entries.fullText: The Doctor called
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a short entry about receiving a visit from the doctor.

entries.fullText: no call
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a short entry about not receiving any visitors.

entries.fullText: No call
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a short entry about not receiving any visitors.

entries.fullText:
Dr. Ricker came
home this A.M. - but
did not call.
entries.summaryText: Dr. Ricker came home but did not call.

entries.fullText:
To day - Dr. Sherman
Ricker called on me -
I began to feel better very soon.
entries.summaryText: Dr. Sherman Ricker called on me and I began to feel better.

entries.fullText:
This is Susie B.'s birthday
- she would have been
32 years of age - she was
born Sept. 21, 1872 - 32 years -
who can tell how grand a
woman she might have been -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her late niece Susie B.'s birthday and wonders how great of a woman she could have been.

entries.fullText:
My last visit
to Ms Louisa Southworth
844. Prospect Street - Cleveland, O
Sister Mary went with me
- she had a room upstairs
I had the one down stairs
that used to be her sons - her
daughter Mary was at home
and very nice -
entries.summaryText: Visit to Ms Louisa Southworth in Cleveland, O with Sister Mary and daughter Mary.

entries.fullText:
Spent the day at Mrs
Soouthworth's - she seemed
very much improved - he
married daughter Fanny & husband and
both her sons and their wives
called - all seemed more
pleasant & satisfactory to her
than ever - Mrs Marie [?]
[Jerv?] Rowe - came while we at
tea with niece Anna O. Bacon -
who has two girl babies now
entries.summaryText: Visit to Mrs. Soouthworth's, meeting with family and friends.

entries.fullText:
We went to Warren, Ohio
this A M. - Mrs Upton gave
a reception - & we had a meeting
in the Opera House - in [?]
it was a splendid meeting - house
packed -
entries.summaryText: Visit to Warren, Ohio, reception and meeting in the Opera House.

entries.fullText:
At Warren O. Harriet
Taylor Uptons - in a Business
Committee meeting - Miss Shaw
the President, Mrs Catt, vice Pres, Miss
Gordon Cr. Scy, - Mrs Blackwell Rec. Scy.
Miss Clay and Mrs Cora Smith Eaton.
& Mrs McCulloch - the legal
advisor - were all there - &
Sister Mary [?own] -
entries.summaryText: Business committee meeting at Harriet Taylor Uptons' in Warren with several attendees including Miss Shaw, Mrs Catt, Miss Gordon, Mrs Blackwell, Miss Clay, Mrs Cora Smith Eaton, Mrs McCulloch, and Sister Mary [?own].

entries.fullText: At Mrs Uptons -
entries.summaryText: No significant events mentioned.

entries.fullText: At Mrs Upton's
entries.summaryText: No significant events mentioned.

entries.fullText:
We left Warren on the
9 P.M. train - [?] a good
business meeting
entries.summaryText: Left Warren after a good business meeting.

entries.fullText:
We arrived this morning - - Mary
went to cousin Dickinson and
I went to Mrs Gross - -
good meeting in P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Illinois with Mary and attended a good meeting.

entries.fullText:
There met at Cousin
Melissa Dick -Cousin Susan
Ready & husband - Niece Maggie
McLean Baker - and other friends
Cousin Hannah & Katie
were there -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony met with family and friends at Cousin Melissa Dick's place.

entries.fullText:
The Jewish Women's
Council meeting - an
immense audience - Mrs
Hannah Solomon running for
Trustee of State University - Cousin
Hannah Boyles & Mrs Gross went
to meet - then Mrs Gross took
us to the 6. o'clock Rock
Island train for Leavenworth -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a Jewish Women's Council meeting and met with Mrs. Hannah Solomon, Cousin Hannah Boyles, and Mrs. Gross.

entries.fullText:
We arrived in Leavenworth
at 10.30 - Found brother
D.R. at the station to meet us -
but Oh so changed - Had
a warm welcome from sister
Annie - & Maud came down to see us
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Leavenworth and met with her brother D.R., sister Annie, and Maud.

entries.fullText:
We all went to dinner
with Maud - & her Lewis -
Brother Daniel sister arriving
D.R. Jr, Bessie & Mary and
me - It was the last time he went
out to dinner -
entries.summaryText: Went to dinner with Maud, Lewis, Brother Daniel, D.R. Jr, Bessie, and Mary. It was the last time Brother Daniel went out to dinner.

entries.fullText:
Brother D.R. Sister Mary& I
went to Lawrence on the morning
train - we drove immediately to the
Park - where they were celebrating the
50th anniversary of the first settlement
of the city - Brother D.R. was so
weak & short hearted that he couldn't
go on the Platform - we took dinner at the
Eldridge House - and went back to Leaven
[?] on P.M. train - it was too bad
that he went - he did not enjoy it -
it was the last time he went out from
home -
entries.summaryText: Went to Lawrence to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the first settlement of the city with Brother D.R. and Sister Mary. Brother D.R. was too weak to go on the platform and it was the last time he went out from home.

entries.fullText:
We staid at home -
brother D.R. used up with
his trip to Lawrence --
entries.summaryText: Stayed at home. Brother D.R. was used up with his trip to Lawrence.

entries.fullText:
Sisters Annie, Mary & I
went to Paul Havens to dinner
at 5 Oclock - Eleanor
took sundry pictures of us.
brother Dan. could
not go - he felt too ill -
entries.summaryText: Went to Paul Havens to dinner with Sisters Annie and Mary. Brother Dan could not go because he felt too ill.

entries.fullText: At Leavenworth
entries.summaryText: Short journal entry stating that Susan B. Anthony was at Leavenworth on October 9th, 1904.

entries.fullText: At Leavenworth
entries.summaryText: Short journal entry stating that Susan B. Anthony was at Leavenworth on October 10th, 1904.

entries.fullText: At Leavenworth
entries.summaryText: Short journal entry stating that Susan B. Anthony was at Leavenworth on October 11th, 1904.

entries.fullText: At Leavenworth
entries.summaryText: Short journal entry stating that Susan B. Anthony was at Leavenworth on October 12th, 1904.

entries.fullText: At Leavenworth
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Leavenworth.

entries.fullText:
Left Leavenworth Kansas at
5.20 P.M. on the Rock Island -
had good night - Left dear
brother D.R. very weak & pale
- he seems destined to go -
but I hope against hope that
he may recover -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Leavenworth and is worried about her brother D.R.'s health.

entries.fullText:
Maud & her Lewis Koehler
left the Fort - with their troops
for the Presidio - San Francisco -
this A.M. at 10 Oclock - Brother
D.R. & Sister Annie drove
up to the Fort to see them start
on the Santa Fe Route - Mrs
Gross met Mary & me at the R. Island
station took us to Mrs Walton & staid
there to dinner with us - & then took
us to Nickle Plate Road - train depot -
Cousin [?] in a bad condition after
[?] -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's family members leave for San Francisco and she meets with Mrs. Gross and Mary.

entries.fullText:
Mary & I arrived home at
11 A.M. - and found all right at
[?] - I hastily looked through
the hundred or more letters that had
accumulated during our three week
absence - and slept in the afternoon.
- It is good to be at home
but I keep up on thinking
about brother D. R. should
never see him alive
again
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony returns home and goes through her mail, but is still worried about her brother D.R.'s health.

entries.fullText:
Read letters - again - and
left at 2.30 for [?] N.Y.
to Eliza Wright Osborn's -
there I found Ellen Wright Garrison
& her oldest daughter Agnes, a
great surprise - Anna Shaw - &
Lucy C. - and Nicolas S. Frazer - Homer
Mary Mills, Emily Howland there - Mrs
Gannet with us. Sister Mary went
to hotel - 9 in all - at Mrs Osborns
- a splendid reception this evening -
some hundred came - went to
bed tired enough -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Eliza Wright Osborn's in N.Y. and meets with several people.

entries.fullText:
The N.Y. State annual Convention -
25th but 35th Con. - Elizas
mother was the first President
the Society was formed in
at Saratoga Springs - 1869 -
Cousin Ellen Hoxie
Squier died this day
at her house - at South
Orange
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the N.Y. State annual Convention and Cousin Ellen Hoxie Squier dies.

entries.fullText:
SQUIER - At South Orange, N.J., on Oct. 18,
Ellen Hoxie, widow of Lucien B. Squier, aged
72 years.
Funeral services at her late residence, South
Orange, on Friday morning, Oct. 21, on arrival
of D., L. & W. train leaving foot Barclay St.
at 10:10 A.M.

[I did not get this dispatch]
They did not send
a telegram - thinking
we were in Leavenworth
still -
entries.summaryText: Ellen Hoxie Squier's obituary and funeral arrangements are announced.

entries.fullText:
A letter came this
P.M. - Sister Mary did open
mail - so I didn't get home
until evening - and so I could
not go to New York - to the
funeral of Cousin Ellen -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a letter from Sister Mary and misses Cousin Ellen's funeral in New York.

entries.fullText: Cousin Ellen Hoxie Squier was buried this day - I was glad that Charels Dickinson & Charles D. Boyles were there - and nephew Dr Gary Baker - & cousin Carrie Vail Ladd - - If I could not be with them - sent a Telegram - niece Louise Mosher James was there
entries.summaryText: Cousin Ellen Hoxie Squier was buried and Susan B. Anthony was glad that some family members were there.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home.

entries.fullText: at home with stenographer answering letters that had accumulated the last month
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home answering letters with a stenographer.

entries.fullText:
Wea. TUES. OCT. 25, 1904 Ther.
at home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote on October 25, 1904, that she was at home.

entries.fullText: Wea. WEDNESDAY 26 Ther.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote on October 26, 1904, that she was at home.

entries.fullText:
Wea. THUR. OCT. 27, 1904 Ther.
at home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote on October 27, 1904, that she was at home.

entries.fullText: Wea. FRIDAY 28 Ther.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote on October 28, 1904, that she was at home.

entries.fullText:
Brother D.R. had very
bad night - and they
thought he was gone during this
this day -
entries.summaryText: Brother D.R. had a bad night and they thought he was gone during the day.

entries.fullText:
Nephew D.R. Jr. telegraphed
that Father was more comfortable -
It is dreadful to hold one's
breath any time the door
bell rings - expecting it is a
telegram telling of death
of brother D.R. and then we
must be off for Leavenworth -
entries.summaryText: Nephew D.R. Jr. telegraphed that Father was more comfortable. They dread receiving a telegram about the death of brother D.R. and having to go to Leavenworth.

entries.fullText:
Anna Dann Mason
at Homeopathic Hosptial - born
a girl baby - at 3 Oclock - doing
nicely - Dr Sherman Ricker
telephoned us - I am glad she
is through the ordeal safely -
A letter from Sister Annie
written Sunday - Brother D.R. very bad.
Saturday - so they thot he was gone
for a time - was put to sleep
on morphine & strychnine - slept
8 hours - woke exhausted -
entries.summaryText: Anna Dann Mason gave birth to a girl at Homeopathic Hospital and is doing well. Sister Annie wrote a letter saying Brother D.R. was very bad on Saturday and was put to sleep on morphine and strychnine, sleeping for 8 hours and waking up exhausted.

entries.fullText:
Letter from Sister Annie
saying brother D.R. was now quiet -
knew friend [Dam??] for a moment -
Helen Stanton -
Theodores second daughter -
Coming on 9.5- train to night
met her at station - saw Theodore
for a moment - it is two years
since he was here at his mothers
funeral = - Nellie looks very
much like Maggie Stanton -
entries.summaryText: Susan receives a letter from her sister Annie about her brother D.R. and meets Helen Stanton, Theodore's second daughter, at the train station.

entries.fullText:
Helen Stanton is a
nice girl of 15 - took her
driving in A.M. to Eastmans - then
bought a Robach - then to the falls
& home - she left one the 4. train
for Geneva - Mrs Smith [Nic?les?]

STEBBINS - In this city, Tuesday, November
8, 1904, at the residence of her brother,
George T. Fish, Catharine A.. F. Stebbins,
widow of the late Giles B. Stebbins, of
Detroit, Mich., in the 82nd year of her
age.
entries.summaryText: Susan takes Helen Stanton driving and to see some sights before she leaves on the train. An obituary for Catharine A. F. Stebbins is included.

entries.fullText: Wea. THUR. NOV 10, 1904 Ther.
Wea. FRIDAY 11 Ther.

Wea. SAT. NOV. 12, 1904 Ther.
89th Birthday of Mrs Stanton
Brother Daniel Read Anthony
died this A.M. - Sister Mary
& I to go to Leavenworth this P.M. at
5.20 - got to Chicago Sunday A.M. 8-
and at - L. at 10 Monday A.M.
so we go. he is our last brother
only Sister Mary & self left -

Democrat Chronicle
COL. D. R. ANTHONY DEAD
Famous Kansas Editor Passes Away in
entries.summaryText: Brother Daniel Read Anthony passed away and Susan B. Anthony and Sister Mary are traveling to Leavenworth.

entries.fullText: Ther
entries.summaryText: Journal entry with no significant information

entries.fullText: Ther.
entries.summaryText: Journal entry with no significant information

entries.fullText:
arrived Chicago at 8. A.M.
Went Walton - found Cousin Melissa
gone - went up stairs to Cousin
Fanny's - found [?] [?]
Spent day there - Mrs Springer called
said she would give 400 dollars [underlined] for the
Protest against Congress [?] house
with Criminals, - - she cheered my heart
No! She gave me $25 - The $400 - was in
October when we were in Chicago -
I got it in my head that the Rock Island
(went at 6.20. Cousin Albert went to
station with us - the train had left -
then we [?] one to the Sante Fe
and left at 9.20 - so I [?] my
25 dollars & paid it out as Fair -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Chicago and spent the day with relatives. Mrs. Springer offered to donate $400 for the protest against Congress house with criminals, but only gave $25. Susan B. Anthony got confused about the train schedule and ended up taking the Sante Fe train.

entries.fullText: Wea. Thur. Nov. 10, 194 Ther.
Wea. Friday 11 Ther.

Wea. Sat. Nov. 12, 1904 Ther.
89th Birthday of Mis Stanton

Brother Daniel Read Anthony
died this A.M.- Sister Mary
& I go to Leavenworth this P.M. at
5.20 - get to Chicago Sunday A.M. 8 -
and at L. at 10 Monday A.M.
So we go. he is our last brother
only Sister Mary & self left -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the death of her brother Daniel Read Anthony and her plans to travel to Leavenworth with her sister Mary. She also mentions the 89th birthday of Mis Stanton.

entries.fullText:
Colonel Daniel R. Anthony, the noted
editor of the Leavenworth (Kansas) Times
and brother of Susan B. and Mary S. Anthony,
of Rochester, died at his home
eearly this morning. The news was received
by the Democrat and Chronicle in
the form of an Associated Press dispatch.
Colonel Anthony was 80 years old. Heart
disease was the cause of death. The
Misses Anthony visited their brother only
a few weeks ago. His health had been
failing for some time.
Colonel Daniel Reed Anthony was for
nearly half a century editor and proprietor
of the Leavenworth Times, and during
that time did much to shape the destiny
of his state. He was born at Adams,
Mass., and spent his early years in New
York. He was intimately acquainted with
Thurlow Weed, Horace Greeley and William
H. Seward. His first entry into
Kansas was in 1854 when he led a Free
State party to that state. Soon thereafter
he became connected with newspaper work
and up to the time of his death he was
active in the affairs of the state. He had
served as mayor and postmaster of Leavenworth,
as a member of the Legislature
and in 1886 was made a government director
of the Union Pacific Railroad. He
formerly was a member of the advisory
board of the Associated Press.
Colonel Anthony had visited in Rochester
several times and had many acquaintances here.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's brother, Colonel Daniel R. Anthony, editor of the Leavenworth Times, passed away at the age of 80. The entry provides a brief biography of Colonel Anthony and his accomplishments.

entries.fullText:
We arrived on the Burlington at
11. A.M. just had time to look
on the face of our dear
brother Daniel R. under the glass.
but he seemed so calm & still.
The funeral was at [?20] - Mr Page
read scriptures & made brief prayer
- then at Mt. Muncie the old soldiers
had their ceremony - it was very
touching - & then Page closed by
repeating the Lords Prayer -
and we left all that is mortal
there at the cemetery - but
[*Wea TUESDAY 15 Ther.*]
he still lives closer than
before in the hearts of all
who love him -

Sisters Annie & Mary & self
drove out to the cemetery
this P.M. - The flowers covered
the grave - all was still - there
lay brother J.R. his head to the
north of the monument - Susie
B. and little Annette at his
right and brother J. Merritt
& sister Hannah at the left -
half of our family are at Mt Muncie -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about arriving at Burlington, attending the funeral of Daniel R., visiting the cemetery and driving around the city.

entries.fullText:
In P.M. we drove to
the Fort and called on
Hattie Bitman Bard -
then drove out on the south
end into city on Shawnee
street
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about visiting Hattie Bitman Bard and driving around the south end of the city.

entries.fullText:
Sister Annie, Mary
& I took a long drive
out west of City - Riding in
the fresh air seems to be
the life of Sister Annie -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about taking a long drive with Annie and Mary out west of the city.

entries.fullText:
Left L. at 5. with D.R. Jr.
went to Hiawatha - to see Webster
Wilder - found him at Station -
his wife - & wife's mother & he make
the family - their youngest daughter
Sarah is in the University - had
a good visit - Web. was in brother
Dan's mind - he thought he could
write his life - but I saw
at once that he was too
feeble -
entries.summaryText: Visit to Webster Wilder in Hiawatha.

entries.fullText:
At 2.30 - nephew D.R. came
from Nebraska farm - he & his
wife both came to station -
I looked at the Huron
farm as we passed it -
