how much pride brother Dan
did take in it - nephew Dan
now will have to look after
both farms - the Times Office -
& his Mayor's business - a
pretty big load for a young man - 34 -
entries.summaryText: Visit from nephew D.R. from Nebraska and discussion of brother Dan's properties.

entries.fullText:
Annie O. Sister Mary & self drove
out to cemetery - the last look at
the earth that covers brother D.R. and
there to lie [?].

(This for the 21st
Train two hours late but
Mrs Gross' man came for us - it
was his 3rd coming to the depot)

Went to Mt Muncie - Annie,
Mary & I Left Leavenworth at 4.30
Burlington - Sister Annie came
to depot - Dannie - Bessie & little
Eleanor & Dan . 3rd - came in their
automobile - it was a sad leaving
- Brother Dan had always gone
with me to East L. on to M.C.
- now he was still in Mt. Muncie -
entries.summaryText: Visit to cemetery and Mt Muncie with family members to pay respects to brother D.R.

entries.fullText:
It was near noon when
we got to the Gross - she had do
girl - her mother was with
her - it is cruel the way she is
left -
The man took us to station
at 9. & we got to bed before the
southern Michigan started -
entries.summaryText: Visit to Gross and departure from southern Michigan.

entries.fullText:
We reached home at 5.20
P.M. - I should not get up
to eat breakfast at Cleveland.
there was no diner on the train -
So was hungry - Carrie was gone
to her niece's - & didn't get back
until 9 Oclock - so sister Mary
picked up what she could,
we had a good supper &
went to bed - met an Englishman
& wife on train -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her sister Mary return home from Cleveland and have dinner with an English couple they met on the train.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Gannett telegraphed
to learn if we were home - [?]
invited us to thanksgiving Dinner
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a telegram from Mrs. Gannett inviting her to Thanksgiving dinner.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary & self went to
Rev. & Mrs Gannetts to Thanksgiving
Dinner - had a nice time -
though it rained when we
came home
When we got home - Mrs
Anthony telephoned that Maria
Anthony had died - she
had been in a comatose state
for [?] days - she was 74, - she
is to be buried Sunday - she has
been loong affliction - it is a happy
release -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her sister Mary have Thanksgiving dinner with Rev. & Mrs. Gannett. Later, they receive news that Maria Anthony has passed away after a long illness.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary went at 5 20
about the funeral preparations
of Maria Anthony - the only
daughter of Asa & Mildred Griffin
Anthony - & sister of D.M. Anthony -
She had a lonely life - lived
in upper rooms - alone &
until she was sick & had
a nurse -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's sister Mary goes to make funeral preparations for Maria Anthony, who had a lonely life and passed away after a long illness.

entries.fullText:
At home and worrying
with my under plate - it now
has two front teeth on it.
I called at D.M.
Anthonys - Mr Gannett
called at our House while I was there
and asked about Maria
- Mary couldn't tell him
very much -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home and visits D.M. Anthonys. Mr Gannett also visits and asks about Maria.

entries.fullText:
Cold & stormy - so didn't
go to Church - but in the
P.M. went to D.M. Anthony's
Funeral of Maria Anthony - She
was brought to his house - Rev
Gannett spoke - It was very
cold & snowy - I rode
up to Mt Hope - but didn't
get out of carriage - the rest
did & almost froze - so
that is the last of poor Maria
I do hope, if she knows, that it will be happy
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the funeral of Maria Anthony at D.M. Anthony's house. Rev Gannett spoke. Susan rode up to Mt Hope but didn't get out of the carriage.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home.

entries.fullText:
A type writer came today -
- she has never been to high
school - even - it is strange
vocabulary to her = It is so
bad for the girl that the
teachers of Stenography do not
tell them that it is no use - to
study, that they cannot be first
class unless they have at least
mastered a High School Studies
It is too bad -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a typewriter. She comments on the lack of education provided to stenography students.

entries.fullText:
At home - Dictating
Letters - with [?] girl
entries.summaryText: Dictating letters at home with someone.

entries.fullText:
at home -
Letters
entries.summaryText: At home writing letters.

entries.fullText:
This is our dear mother's
111th Birthday - Now she & dear
father have their Dan'l R. added
to the number - on that side -
We had 12. to our Turkey Dinner
Mrs. L.C. Smith - 94 - Mrs S.L. Willis 87 -
Mrs. Hallowell 83 - Mrs Wilbur Griffing
74 - Mrs Wildey Dupre, 74 - Mrs
Blackall and Mrs Wattkey [over] 71,
Mrs Morse 62, Mrs D.M. Anthony 60,
Mrs Bedell 58 - Mrs Gannett - 50
Sister Mary 77, SB.A. 85 -!!
entries.summaryText: Celebrating mother's 111th birthday with family and friends.

entries.fullText:
When the girl came to [?]
she said she didn't think
she could do to suit - & I paid
her $6.. and said I thought
so too -
entries.summaryText: Paying someone $6 who didn't think they could do the job well.

entries.fullText: Went Church - Mr Burridge of Albany preacher asked Mr Osborn if he could send me a girl who knew where to make a period, comma & how to spell - Mrs Elizabeth Marsh Glover overhearing - said "What is the matter with me" - & Mr Osborn said - nothing - but in an aside he said she would do more in one hour than an ordinary girl [in a day]
entries.summaryText: Attended church and discussed finding a typist with Mr Burridge and Mr Osborn. Mrs Elizabeth Marsh Glover offered to help.

entries.fullText: She at once struck a bargain - and she came for a half day this morning - and we got off 12 [underlined] beautiful letters - I think she is going to do nicely - I only want a girl a half a day - and sister Mary rest - She has husband & mother & keeps house - so a half day pleases her
entries.summaryText: Hired a typist for half a day and was pleased with the work done.

entries.fullText: I entirely forgot to send a letter to the Kansas Historical Society [title underlined] that meets 15 day - it will be the first one that brother D.R. has been absent from - Had my typewriter to day - she is first rate - D. Webster Wilder sent splendid Resolutions to the Historical meeting -
entries.summaryText: Forgot to send a letter to the Kansas Historical Society. Received a typewriter and D. Webster Wilder sent resolutions to the Historical meeting.

entries.fullText: Brother D. R. was represented at the Historical society's meeting by his only son - Daniel Read Anthony Junior - I am very glad nephew D. R. A. Jr. went he became a member & later a Life member. I am so glad -
entries.summaryText: Brother D. R. was represented at the Historical society's meeting by his son, Daniel Read Anthony Junior.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Glover set her
price at 50 cts an
hour - which would be
at the rate of 9 dollars a
week - if she comes a
half of every day -
entries.summaryText: Mrs Glover sets her price at 50 cents an hour.

entries.fullText:
Paid Mrs Glover
5 1/2 dollars for this
week - she called it
11 hours - I think it
better than employing
a poor Stenographer a week
entries.summaryText: Paid Mrs Glover $5.50 for 11 hours of work.

entries.fullText:
I didn't go to Church
- it was stormy & slippery -
he preached is 1,000- [underlined] sermon
entries.summaryText: Missed church due to bad weather.

entries.fullText: Wea. MON. DEC. 12, 1904 Ther.
Wea. TUESDAY 13 Ther.

Sent Henry D. Stanton's
Recollections - to D. Webster
Wilder Hiawatha - Kansas -
entries.summaryText: Sent Henry D. Stanton's Recollections to D. Webster and Wilder in Hiawatha, Kansas.

entries.fullText:
Brother D.R.'s wife -
Annie Osborn Anthony -
started for California - to day
over the Union Pacific R.R. - to see
or make Maud 6 weeks visit -
I know it was pretty hard
for her to shut up her homes
It is just a month since brother
D.R. was buried - what a change -
Lizzie Bittman went
with sister Annie
entries.summaryText: Annie Osborn Anthony started a six-week visit to Maud in California via Union Pacific R.R. with Lizzie Bittman. Mentions the recent death of brother D.R.

entries.fullText:
The gloves did not come.
Got off by Wells Fargo Express -
History & life to - Rachel Foster Avery -
Mll [?edart] & Madame [Ch?affremi?r]
& Dr. Aletta H. Jacobs - in her
old [?] - and looked
over the books - accounts
of History -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about gloves that did not arrive and meeting with Rachel Foster Avery, Mll [?edart], Madame [Ch?affremi?r], and Dr. Aletta H. Jacobs to look over the accounts of History.

entries.fullText:
Carrie went to the Wm Prince
her niece's - to dinner - her sister
Mary does their work & her niece Ella
cooks with them - Sister Mary
& self remained at home and
eat split pea soup - splendid - &
had a good day - Sister Mary
went to Church - but I staid
at home - & took stitches in my
new lemon suits - Patton - & made
them ready to put on New
Years day - [?] &her family gone
to Albion - to [?] [?] & her baby
entries.summaryText: Carrie went to Wm Prince's niece's for dinner. Susan and Sister Mary stayed home and had split pea soup. Sister Mary went to church while Susan took stitches in her new lemon suits. Carrie's family went to Albion.

entries.fullText:
Wea. Saturday 31 Ther.
This is brother Aaron
M. McLeans birth day - he
was born in 1812 -- he died
Jan. 18, 1896 - - he was 84 - he
would have been 94 to day
- Dear Sister Guelma
entries.summaryText: Journal entry dated December 31, 1904. Mentions Aaron M. McLean's birthday and death, and a message to Sister Guelma.
